title: R44268
content: During the Vietnam War, Operation Ranch Hand sprayed millions of gallons of herbicides, including Agent Orange, over southern Vietnam. The herbicides contained TCDD, a toxic carcinogen. Dioxin "hot spots" have been identified in areas like Bien Hoa, Danang, and the A Luoi Valley. The environmental damage and health issues caused by Agent Orange have prompted a response from the U.S. The A Luoi Valley was heavily sprayed with herbicides during the Vietnam War. The U.S. is addressing the environmental damage and health problems caused by Agent Orange in Vietnam, which has helped improve bilateral relations. President Obama pledged to assist in removing unexploded landmines, bombs, and dioxin contamination at Bien Hoa Air Base. The joint effort with Vietnam to clean up dioxin at Danang Airport is nearly complete. The United States has successfully completed the first phase of dioxin remediation at Danang International Airport, with the final phase ongoing. They are committed to partnering with Vietnam to clean up dioxin contamination at Bien Hoa Air Base. The Trump Administration continues to provide assistance to address the Agent Orange/dioxin issue. Both countries are working together on war legacy issues, including dioxin remediation, and have made progress at Da Nang Airport. The environmental remediation project at Danang Airport has been a key focus since 2008. The environmental remediation project at Danang Airport in Vietnam, funded by congressional appropriations related to Agent Orange/dioxin, experienced delays, increased material for decontamination, and rising costs. The project, initiated in 2008, aimed to complete by October 2013 but was finished in August 2017, with costs escalating from $33.7 million to over $110 million. Soil at the airport had high levels of "TCDD toxic equivalents," reaching 365 parts per billion. The joint military/civilian airport in Danang had high levels of "TCDD toxic equivalents" in the soil, exceeding international standards. A project initiated in 2009 aimed at environmental health and remediation programs, with USAID and Office 33 as implementing agencies. The project included a grant for dioxin containment design at Danang airport. USAID completed an Environmental Assessment in 2010 recommending thermal desorption for remediation. In June 2010, USAID completed an Environmental Assessment of Danang airport recommending thermal desorption for decontamination of contaminated material. The project aimed to remediate 61,700 m3 of material in six hotspots at the airport, with an estimated cost of $33.7 million. USAID and Vietnam's Ministry of National Defence signed a Memorandum of Intent in December 2010 to start the project in 2011 and complete it by October 2013. USAID awarded contracts for the environmental remediation in July 2012 to CDM Smith. In April 2011, MND approved the project. USAID issued an RFP in May 2011 and awarded contracts in July 2012 to CDM Smith and Tetra Tech for the environmental remediation of Danang airport. The project officially started on August 20, 2012. An internal audit in November 2014 revealed six contracts awarded for the project, including thermal desorption of contaminated soil in two phases. The thermal desorption of contaminated soil at Danang airport was done in two phases, with Phase 1 starting in April 2014 and Phase 2 in January 2015. The project was delayed due to weather and additional soil testing revealing more contamination than estimated. The excavation and construction progress at Danang airport was hindered by weather conditions from September to December. More soil and sediment than expected needed decontamination after drainage of small lakes. The secondary treatment facility was closed in July 2014 for a filter system change. Raising the soil temperature to 335°C took longer than planned. An audit by USAID's Office of Inspector General in November 2014 highlighted risks like inclement weather and soil cooling delays. The audit recommended implementing a formal risk management plan, providing accurate performance data, fulfilling training obligations, and improving data documentation. A cleanup of the dioxin "hot spot" at Bien Hoa airbase is being explored after the completion of the Danang airport cleanup. Soil samples from Bien Hoa show high levels of dioxin contamination. The Bien Hoa airbase in Vietnam, a site of extensive herbicide storage and use during the war, has high levels of dioxin contamination. Mitigation measures have been taken, including the creation of a passive landfill for contaminated soil. However, other dioxin "hot spots" remain unaddressed, with contaminated soil spreading into nearby water bodies. The United Nations Development Programme is working on a master plan for dioxin remediation at the airbase. The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has been working with Office 33 and MONRE for five years to map out dioxin contamination at Bien Hoa airbase. An estimated 408,500 to 495,300 m3 of contaminated soils and sediments are located on or nearby the airbase, requiring treatment. Five different treatment methods were considered, with costs ranging from $137 million to $794 million. The estimated costs for environmental remediation at Bien Hoa Airbase range from $137 million to $794 million, with potential variations of 40% less to 75% more. Over $3.7 million has been allocated for assessment, and construction work with a budget of $11.8 million has begun for dioxin decontamination. USAID and Vietnam's Ministry of National Defence have signed a memorandum of intent to start the decontamination process. On January 23, 2018, USAID and Vietnam's Ministry of National Defence signed a memorandum of intent to decontaminate Bien Hoa airport. The agreement commits the two nations to work together on a remediation program for the airport, with a five-year, $183 million aid agreement signed in May 2018. The project is estimated to take 10 years and decontaminate 500,000 cubic meters of soil. In September 2018, a memorandum of understanding was signed with the Japanese contractor, Shimizu Corporation, to construct a decontamination factory at the airport. The Ministry of National Defence signed a memorandum with Shimizu Corporation to build a decontamination factory at Bien Hoa airport. The factory will use a new technique to decontaminate soil and is expected to be more cost-effective than previous methods. U.S. Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis visited the airport and expressed America's commitment to remediate past issues.
